So far, Sir, I have dealt only with the economic effects of quantitative restrictions. What are the administrative problems associated with them? I have already mentioned the difficulty of measuring the correct size of the import quota. I notice that the bill says that a special adviser is, in the case of quantitative restrictions, to recommend what should be the level of protection. I am not quite sure what that means, but I understand that the special adviser is not expected to decide the quota. Does the department do it? The department fixes the quota and, having done that, parcels out licences amongst the importers, resulting in trafficking in licences again and all the special pleading which we remember so clearly from the import licensing days. Who is to get the licences? Will it be the importer who, when import licensing was lifted, joined in the mad scramble for imports in case licensing was imposed again? I should have thought that this was a responsibility which any wise department would be glad to forgo. It appears that the department is grasping at it again.

When discussing these questions with my colleagues I am often taunted with the protection given to primary industries. I admit that much of the protection so given is sloppily conceived and untidily executed. But it is worth remembering that in almost every case in which primary industry is protected there is a limit placed on the price that can be charged for the particular commodities in Australia. In this regard, butter and sugar are clear examples. The Minister for Trade seemed conveniently to forget this when he made his attack on Mr. Havard, the president of the National Farmers Union of Australia. If the Government were to impose price and output controls in the case of those products of secondary industry in respect of which it grants quotas, my guns would be silenced. But 1 have heard nothing of this.

There is one particular group which stood by us in 1960 when the Government took what was obviously unpopular action for the sake of the economy. The farmer organizations felt that this action, though unpopular, had to be taken in order to keep inflation in control. Is this to be their reward? They having stood by us in our most difficult time, will we now enact legislation which rightly fills them with apprehension, and which is certain to add to their costs?

I oppose this bill, Sir, but I will not vote against it. What is the use? If I did so and the Government were to fall, we would have a Labour Government, committed to selective import licensing as a matter of course, not as an exception, as is the Government's stated intention here. But I appeal to the Government to have a careful look at this matter during the time that must elapse before the bill is again brought before the House, and to weigh carefully the criticisms that I have made against the legislation. I can see no reason for the proposed alterations, and I see great danger in them. It seems to me that the Government has bowed to a well-mounted, unprincipled attack by the chambers of manufactures. I admit that our political majority is precarious, but to seek popularity at this price will erode the morale of our parties and rightly alienate the support of the exporting section of the community.

Can he also say whether the New South Wales Citrus Growing Council recently decided to cut supplies by 25 per cent.?
Were the decisions of these organizations prompted by a desire to raise the retail prices of the commodities produced by their members?

Is organized marketing the alternative to wholesale dumping of products such as bananas and citrus fruits; if so, have any steps been taken to initiate a marketing authority which, among other things, would guarantee a fair return to producers and a reasonable price to consumers?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1,2 and 3.
item.para: I understand thai the heavy supplies of both bananas and citrus fruits available for the Sydney market in recent months have created marketing problems. However, I have not had any approach from the industry organizations concerned, which is quite logical since internal marketing within any State is constitutionally the responsibility of the State concerned.

No approach has been made to the Commonwealth on organized marketing arrangements for these products. As I said in the House earlier in this session in reply to questions by the honorable members for Richmond and Moore, I would be prepared on receipt of submissions from the banana industry to have the matter discussed in the Australian Agricultural Council. That offer applies also to the citrus industry.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development, upon notice -

item.para: Will Australia lose the benefit of the great collection of planners, engineers, technicians and contractors gathered together under the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority if i he authority is not granted a further assignment?
As such a loss would be most undesirable, Is the Government giving consideration to a new assignment for the authority following completion of the current project?

If so, in studying this matter, will the Minister consider national development in central Queensland, and in view of the great natural resources of that area, give consideration to the planning of industrial development there?

Is it possible for the Commonwealth to organize an overall plan, similar to (hat adopted for the Snowy Mountains, for the development of this area under which an authority could be assigned the project of providing a steel mill, an electricity undertaking and aluminium smelters, improving port facilities at Gladstone Harbour and developing the vast quantities of bauxite, iron ore and coal which are situated close to that port?
Would the establishment of such a body constitute a great step forward in the development of Queensland?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: The resources of the Snowy Mountains Authority will be fully committed for some years at least in completing the formidable programme that lies ahead of it. It is impossible to predict what development projects might appropriately be carried out by the authority. For these reasons the Government has not under consideration at the present time any particular new assignment for the authority. Already the authority is being called upon to carry out a growing number of specialist assignments appropriate to its particular skills and experience, such as arc described on page 32 of the authority's annual report for the year ended 30th June, 1961, which was tabled in Parliament recently. These calls upon the authority's services are expected lo increase.

The Commonwealth is already engaged, in cooperation with the appropriate State departments and authorities in resources surveys of cast-central Queensland. The Commonwealth agencies engaged in this work are C.S.I.R.O. (Land Research and Regional Survey), Department of Primary Industry (Bureau of Agricultural Economics), Department of National Development (Resources, Information and Development Branch). The results will be published in the form of maps and commentaries. The Commonwealth has also given special assistance in the form of a grant and loan towards the cost of installation of coal handling facilities at Gladstone.

item.label: 4 and 4.
item.para: The formulation of an overall plan of development of central Queensland is a function of the State Government which in fact has already given considerable attention to the matter. For example, a decision has been made to proceed with a coal-fired electricity generating station near Callide for which an initial expenditure of Â£9,200,000 has been approved. The complete installation is estimated to cost Â£23,500,000. The industrial operations to which the question relates are primarily the concern of private industry. Much of the investigational work required for coal development has been completed and firm proposals for their development have been announced. The extensive low-grade iron ore deposits of the Dawson Valley are also under active investigation. There are no bauxite deposits of any consequence near Gladstone.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice -

item.para: Is he able to say whether there are in West New Guinea native residents of that Territory who have reached a sufficiently high educational standard lo enable them to form a judgment as to the future political control of their country?
If so, has any endeavour been made either by the Netherlands, Indonesia or the United Nations to ascertain the views of these people?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: The West New Guinea Council, on which there is a majority of Papuans, recently passed a resolution setting the year 1970 as the latest date for the exercise of self-determination. I can only conclude that the Papuan members of that Council consider that it will be some years before a sufficient proportion of their fellow-countrymen will have reached a sufficiently high standard of education and political consciousness to form a judgment as to the future political control of their country. My own information is to the same effect.
Docs not arise.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Trade, upon notice -

item.para: Was there any discussion between the Governments of Malaya and Australia on the question of the sale of bauxite before the announcement concerning the sale to Japan of bauxite from Weipa?
Is the price of bauxite in this contract below the price at which Indonesia and Malaya sell to Japan at present?
If so, what effects are the results of increased sales on this basis likely to have on the economy of Malaya?

talk.start.para: - I have received from the Acting Minister for Trade the following answers to the honorable member's questions: -

item.para: The sale of bauxite to Japan was a normal commercial transaction carried out by a private company, and I am not aware of any discussions on the matter between the Governments of Malaya and Australia.
Bauxite prices vary according to the quality of the material and a simple comparison of the prices being paid for bauxite from various sources would be misleading.

Malayan sales of bauxite to Japan would not necessarily be affected by shipments from Australia which, so far, have been only experimental tonnages. Japan's total imports from all sources are steadily rising. Japan does not draw her supplies from any single source, but obtains bauxite from such sources as India, Indonesia and North Borneo as well as from Malaya. The actual position so far as Malaya is concerned is that one of the deposits from which Japan has been drawing some supplies is almost exhausted. It is only natural, therefore, for Japan to seek alternative sources of supply. _.....__ ,

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: Has the Department of Civil Aviation any plans in hand to establish an international restaurant at Eagle Farm Airport, Brisbane?
If so, is it proposed that a liquor licence be granted to this restaurant?
Has the department any plans for this air port to be declared a permanent international entry or exit airport for overseas tourists?
Are there any plans to demolish the wartime igloo now serving as the Trans-Australia Airlines terminal at Eagle Farm and for its replacement by a terminal similar to that at Mascot, Sydney?

If there are no such plans for the development of this airport, will the Minister arrange for his department to carry out an inspection and investigation at Eagle Farm with a view to bringing the installations, passenger conveniences, services and terminal up to the same standard as those now existing at and planned for Mascot?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Civil Aviation has supplied the following answers to the honorable member's questions: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: The department does not have any plans for the establishment of a restaurant in the international terminal. Some consideration has been given to the establishment of a cocktail lounge in that terminal, but no firm plans have been made.

Brisbane airport is a designated international airport of entry and departure at the present time and has been so for many years. Apart from the services between Brisbane and New Guinea, Qantas includes Brisbane on its Boeing service to London.
Trans-Australia Airlines has recently completed extensive improvements to its terminal; no further improvements are planned at present.

The facilities now in operation at Brisbane airport, while of a semi-permanent nature are generally adequate for the passengers and visitors who use it. Provision has been made in the overall planning of the airport for a new terminal area to be built at a later date, the existing area then reverting to use for hangars and workshops. Such a development will involve very considerable expenditure, not only on buildings but on the associated aprons, taxiways, roads and parking areas. It is intended to bring this new terminal area into operation by the time that the expected increase in civil aviation builds traffic up to the point where it cannot be adequately handled in the present area. It is estimated that it will be some years yet before this point is reached and, in the meantime, the funds available for civil aviation developments throughout Australia would be applied to projects which must be considered to have greater priority.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice -

item.para: How many (a) male and (b) female natives were arrested at Buka Island following the recent "head tax" incidents?
How many (a) European and (b) native personnel were in the apprehending force?
What casualties were sustained by (a) the apprehending force and (b) the local population?

talk.start.para: The answers that follow assume that the honorable member is referring to incidents at Buka Island early in February. As has been explained it is misleading to refer to them as " head tax " incidents - much more than taxation was involved.

item.para: (a) 461, Cb) nil.

Eight, (b) 1SS. (An additional 400 police arrived in the area on 21st February, 1962, subsequent to the attacks made on the police party on 6th and 19th February, 1962, but before the majority of the leaders voluntarily submitted to arrest on 22nd February, 1962.)
(a) 20 received minor injuries. Two were seriously injured, (b) 71 - none seriously.

No. Most of the arrested persons were transported to Sohano by coastal ships. One hundred and sixty-six who were arrested in the Hahalis area, where there are no safe anchorages, had to walk to Sohano because the only vehicular track was impassable following heavy rain. The distance walked was 25 miles. The arrested persons were not manacled or handcuffed - they simply walked with police on either side.

Magistrates presiding over courts for native affairs are responsible for ensuring that the interests of the defendants are protected. In the cases arising out of the Buka incidents each defendant was asked to plead. Only two defendants pleaded not guilty, but the magistrate, exercising the responsibility placed upon him, directed that in 187 charges pleas of not guilty be entered.
Eight.

Failure to pay personal tax, eight fined 10s. Obstructing police, 272; 167 three months' imprisonment, one one month's imprisonment, 104 fined Â£1. Riotous behaviour, 307; 171 six months' imprisonment, ten two months' imprisonment, 78 one month's imprisonment, 48 fined Â£2. Escaping from custody, two; one six months' imprisonment, one four months' imprisonment.

Of the total adult male population of 115 in Hahalis village 81 have been sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment. There is not a considerable degree of hardship in consequence. Food is abundant. In accordance with custom during the long absence of males, the welfare of the people is being closely guarded by relatives from nearby villages. Administration officers are closely watching conditions to see that no hardship is suffered. The Catholic Mission in the area, subsidized by the Administration, continues to provide health and education services and to assist in general village welfare.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Services, upon notice -

item.para: How many persons in receipt of an invalid pension have a dependent wife and children?
Is he satisfied that every endeavour is being made to rehabilitate invalid pensioners who are suffering from cardiac conditions?
How many age pensioners have a dependent wife and children?
How many pensioners have dependent children?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: The classification " dependent wife and children " is assumed to refer to wives and children for whom wives' and children's allowances are payable. At 12th February, 1962, there were 14,660 cases in which wives' and children's allowances were payable in conjunction with invalid pensions. Of this number, allowances were being paid for both wives and children in 5,005 cases, allowances were being paid for wives only in 6,095 cases, and allowances were being paid for children only in 3,560 cases.

Persons granted invalid pensions, including those with cardiac conditions, are referred to the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service which examines their suitability for rehabilitation assistance. Those considered suitable are given treatment in the department's rehabilitation centres and, where necessary, vocational training, to fit them for suitable work. Experience has shown that a large percentage of sufferers from cardiovascular disease are able to engage in normal employment. At the end of February, 1962, more than 50 persons with cardiac conditions were receiving rehabilitation through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. The Department of Social Services is, of course, maintaining a close liaison in all States with the National Heart Foundation organization which is in the process of establishing clinics to assist in the rehabilitation of persons suffering from cardiac conditions.

No details are held of the number of age pensioners who have families except those who are permanently incapacitated for work. At 12th February, 1962, there were 4,381 cases in which wives' and children's allowances were payable in conjunction with age pensions. Of this number, allowances were being paid for both wives and children in 716 cases, allowances were being paid for wives only in 2,851 cases and allowances were being paid for children only in 814 cases.
At 12th February, 1962, there were 25,752 widow pensioners with children.
